text:
My name is Jamillah
Bowman-Williams.

I'm a professor of law
at Georgetown University,

and I'm also a faculty fellow
here at Harvard Business
School.

Primarily, I study race
and gender inequality

in organizations, and I
look for different solutions

to start solving for some
of these inequalities.

Recently, I've
been looking a lot

at the messaging we use
in organizations to deal

with inequality and looking
for more equity and inclusion
and diversity in organizations.

The primary messaging
and approach

that organizations are
taking are the business case
for diversity.

So saying that
diversity essentially

is bringing benefits and
it's helping the bottom line.
It helps our teams.

It helps our organizations
perform better.

But what this ends up doing
is it leads to a surface level
approach to DEI.

You hire people in,
but you don't actually
change the culture.

You don't change the
system to be a place where

all of that new
talent can actually

thrive and do well and move
up the career trajectory.

So it actually creates
a more of a problem
than it actually solves.

That's the dominant
approach, but yet it

also triggers different
resistance and backlash

and biases that many of our
leaders aren't aware of.

Leaders are overemphasizing
the bottom line

and the rational
arguments for diversity.

So essentially there's
more of a disconnect

the more we make this
an issue of profit

when equity inclusion
are not issues of profit.

It's a time where there's
more accountability now
than there ever has been.

So your employees are
watching, your future employees

are watching, your
customers are watching,
your investors are watching.

So really they're looking
for accountability.

So what I would like for
CEOs to do with this research

is to begin to reflect on the
approaches that they're taking.

If they're really leading
with this business

case for diversity and we
found that it's detrimental,

it may be a time to stop that
approach and try something new.

So once we move away from
monetizing and extracting

profit from people's identities,
we move on to something

where we actually are further
connecting with people.

We're relating to them,
we're hearing their stories,

and that's what actually helps
us close these inequality
gaps in the bigger picture.
